metadata.titleEn: An inventory of retrogressive thaw slumps along the vulnerable Qinghai-Tibet engineering corridor (2019)
metadata.description:
Retrogressive thaw slumps (RTSs) are slope failures caused by the thawing of ice-rich permafrost. Once developed, they usually retreat at high speeds (meters to tens of meters) towards the upslope direction, and the mudflow may destroy infrastructure and release carbon stored in frozen ground. RTSs are frequently distributed in permafrost areas and increase dramatically but lack investigation. Qinghai Tibet Engineering Corridor crosses the permafrost, links the inland and the Tibet. However, in this critical area, we lack knowledge of the distribution and impact of RTSs. To compile the first comprehensive inventory of RTSs, this study uses an iterative semi-automatic method based on deep learning and manual inspection to delineate RTSs in 2019 images. The images from PlanetScope CubeSat have a resolution of 3 meters, have four bands, cover a corridor area of approximately 54,000 square kilometers. The method combines the high efficiency and automation of deep learning and the reliability of the manual inspection to map the entire region ninth, which minimize the missings and misidentification. 
The manual inspection is based on geomorphic features and temporal changes (2016 to 2020) of RTSs. The inventory which includes 875 RTSs with their attributes, including identification, Longitude and Latitude, possibilities and time, provides a benchmark dataset for quantifying permafrost degradation and its impact.
metadata.instructions: The vector file in geopackage / gpkg format contains the boundary of each hot melt collapse. Relevant attribute tables include number, confidence probability, time of satellite image, source of the satellite image, near roads labels, initial year, longitude and latitude, area (unit: m2), and depth learning model used. The corresponding names of the table fields are "Id", "probability", "year-month", "source image", "near road", "initial year", "longitude", "latitude", "area", "deep learning model". "Probability" represents our confidence in the described hot melt collapse, which is divided into "high", "medium" and "low". The file in GIF format shows the time change of each hot melt collapse (from 2016 to 2020), in which the file name format is "rts_id", "Id" corresponds to the vector file.

Quantification.Question: How many thermokarst landslides were identified and documented using deep learning and visual interpretation methods in the data collection process for the Tibetan Plateau region?

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using deep learning and visual interpretation compare to traditional field surveys for identifying thermokarst features in permafrost regions?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method using deep learning and visual interpretation combines the efficiency and automation of deep learning with the reliability of manual interpretation. It enables iterative mapping to minimize omissions and errors, while traditional field surveys may provide more direct and detailed local observations but are typically more time-consuming and labor-intensive.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of deep learning with visual interpretation and field verification enhance the accuracy and reliability of identifying thermokarst features in permafrost regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of deep learning with visual interpretation and field verification enhances accuracy and reliability by combining the efficiency and automation of deep learning with the reliability of manual interpretation. This method allows for iterative mapping to minimize both false negatives and positives by cross-verifying algorithm-drawn features with geomorphological characteristics and temporal changes observed in 2016 to 2020.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate deep learning methods with visual interpretation for identifying thermokarst features in permafrost regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating deep learning methods with visual interpretation is important because it combines the efficiency and automation of deep learning with the reliability of human expertise in visual analysis. This hybrid approach aims to maximize detection accuracy by iteratively mapping potential features, thus reducing false negatives and false positives in identifying thermokarst features along the Qinghai-Tibet engineering corridor. It ensures comprehensive mapping of thermokarst features, which are critical for understanding permafrost degradation and its impacts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be implemented to ensure the reliability and accuracy of identifying and delineating thermokarst landslides using high-resolution remote sensing imagery, particularly when employing deep learning methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve using high-resolution remote sensing imagery, such as the 3-meter resolution PlanetScope microsatellite images, to cover the entire permafrost region of the engineering corridor. A combination of deep learning methods for efficiency and automation, along with manual interpretation for reliability, is used. The process includes iteratively mapping the region approximately ten times to minimize false negatives and false positives. Additionally, visual interpretation is based on geomorphological features and temporal changes from 2016 to 2020 to verify the automatic delineation of thermokarst landslides by the deep learning algorithm.
